root.pub-comments: This chapter follows Kaufman's classification. Kaufman (1990) classifies the languages of South America into 118 genetic units, of which 70 are isolates and 48 are groups consisting of at least two languages that are unquestionably genetically related.
root.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Says the language is distinct from Ava-Canoiero and Kanoe. This language is sometimes considered a part of the Macro-Jê cluster. There is reason to believe that all of these units are related, and research should be undertaken to determine whether this is in fact the case.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Huilliche is a variety of Mapudungu in Argentina.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Kaufman groups together his families/genetic units Cunza, Kapixaná, Betoi, Paezan, Barbacoan, Itonama, and Warao in what he calls the Macro-Paesan cluster…until that work is done, the decision on this broader grouping needs to be held in abeyance.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Culle may be related to Cholonan. It is very poorly documented and is now probably extinct. Given that the total corpus does not exceed 100 poorly recorded words, determination of its genetic affinity may prove very difficult.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Says the language is moribund/obsolescent
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Says the language is obsolescent. Kaufman lists Boran and Witotoan as distinct families which, together with Andoque, perhaps make up what he calls a Boran-Witotoan stock.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Says the language is obsolescent. Plausible sound correspondences have been found for Kaufman's grouping of Kandoshi-Omurano-Taushiro.

child.pub-comments: Sechura-Catacoan-Leco grouping may be possible according to Kaufman. However, he adds that "the hypothesis has not been systematically tested, and all the constituent languages are dead and poorly documented."
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Sometimes grouped with Macro-Jê. There is reason to believe that all of these units are related, and research should be undertaken to determine whether this is in fact the case.

child.pub-comments: Says the language is obsolescent.

child.pub-comments: Kaufman groups together his families/genetic units Cunza, Kapixaná, Betoi, Paezan, Barbacoan, Itonama, and Warao in what he calls the Macro-Paesan cluster…until that work is done, the decision on this broader grouping needs to be held in abeyance.

child.pub-comments: Is unsure whether or not this language is extinct. Greenberg classified Maku with his Macro-Tucanoan, based on some lexical similarities, but Migliazza notes that it also shares similarities with Arawakan languages and with Warao.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: It is perhaps completely undocumented.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Says the language has several dialects. Is sometimes considered a part of a cluster called Macro-Jê. There is reason to believe that all of these units are related, and research should be undertaken to determine whether this is in fact the case.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: The grouping of Puquina with Chipaya-Uru is a frequent mistaken identity; Chipaya and Uru were often called "Puquina" in their local area and by outsiders, although Puquina is a totally distinct language which has almost nothing in common with Chipaya and Uru.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Kaufman indicates that , although this cluster represents the intersection of some opinions about genetic grouping, Tuyoneri, Otomakoan, and Trumai are best treated as independent.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Kaufman indicates that , although this cluster represents the intersection of some opinions about genetic grouping, Tuyoneri, Otomakoan, and Trumai are best treated as independent.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Price thinks this might be related to Nambiquara.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Cofán has borrowed from neighboring Chibchan languages; it remains unclassified, not known to have any broader affiliation.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Says the language is obsolescent.

child.pub-comments: It is best for now to consider Matanawí independent.

child.pub-comments: All the broad classifiers of South American languages except Swadesh group Esmeralda and Yaruro together. The proposal merits study.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Usually grouped with Lule.

child.pub-comments: The name Maina is ambiguous, applied also sometimes to Candoshi and Jivaroan. Has possible connections with Candoshi and Taushiro.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Kaufman also reports Taushiro lexical similarities with Candoshi and Omurano and he therefore assigns it the number 35a to indicate that it has been claimed to be related to Zaparoan but may have the other connections mentioned.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Does not know if the language is extinct. In the early 1970s, there were different reports of two to twelve speakers. Five dialects of the language are sometimes mentioned.

Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

child.pub-comments: Zaparoan and Jivaroan are the main candidates for a genetic grouping to which it may belong.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 6: Languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
